title: partialling_out
text: Let’s make simple linear model first. Using partialling_out function, can get residualised variable interest (bill_length_mm) first explanatory variable (bill_depth_mm), .e. return residuals following two regressions. Accordingly, coefficient res_bill_depth_mm model lm(res_bill_length_mm ~ res_bill_depth_mm) coefficient bill_depth_mm original model. set FALSE, function return actual Y values residualised X values.
code: library(partialling.out) library(tinytable) library(tinyplot) library(palmerpenguins) library(fwlplot) model <- lm(bill_length_mm ~ bill_depth_mm + species, data = penguins) summary(model) #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = bill_length_mm ~ bill_depth_mm + species, data = penguins) #>  #> Residuals: #>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max  #> -8.0300 -1.5828  0.0733  1.6925 10.0313  #>  #> Coefficients: #>                  Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)     #> (Intercept)       13.2164     2.2475    5.88 9.83e-09 *** #> bill_depth_mm      1.3940     0.1220   11.43  < 2e-16 *** #> speciesChinstrap   9.9390     0.3678   27.02  < 2e-16 *** #> speciesGentoo     13.4033     0.5118   26.19  < 2e-16 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #> Residual standard error: 2.518 on 338 degrees of freedom #>   (2 observations deleted due to missingness) #> Multiple R-squared:  0.7892, Adjusted R-squared:  0.7874  #> F-statistic: 421.9 on 3 and 338 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16 modely <- lm(bill_length_mm ~ species, data = penguins)  modelx <- lm(bill_depth_mm ~ species, data = penguins) res <- partialling_out(model, data = penguins)  tt(head(res)) |>   format_tt(digits = 2) |>   style_tt(align = "c") resmodel <- lm(res_bill_length_mm ~ res_bill_depth_mm, data = res)  print(c(model$coefficients[2], resmodel$coefficients[2])) #>     bill_depth_mm res_bill_depth_mm  #>          1.394011          1.394011 tt(head(partialling_out(model, penguins, both = FALSE))) |>   format_tt(digits = 2) |>   style_tt(align = "c")

title: partialling_out
text: weights specified partialling_out used weight underlying partial models. weights also returned column result data.frame. original model weighted partial models aren’t, function throw warning (also original model weighted partial models ). Note , FWL theorem hold, partial models weighted, linear model two residualised variables must weighted well.
code: model <- lm(   bill_length_mm ~ bill_depth_mm + species,   data = penguins,   weights = penguins$body_mass_g ) res <- partialling_out(model, data = penguins, weights = penguins$body_mass_g)   tt(head(res)) |>   format_tt(digits = 2) |>   style_tt(align = "c") unweighted_model <- lm(res_bill_length_mm ~ res_bill_depth_mm, data = res)  weighted_model <- lm(   res_bill_length_mm ~ res_bill_depth_mm,   weights = res$weights,   data = res )   data.frame(   "original model" = model$coefficients[2],   "unweighted model" = unweighted_model$coefficients[2],   "weighted_model" = weighted_model$coefficients[2] ) |>   tt() |>   format_tt(digits = 4) |>   style_tt(align = "c")

title: partialling_out
text: stated, model also work feols felm models
code: library(fixest)  model_fixest <- feols(bill_length_mm ~ bill_depth_mm | species, data = penguins)  res_fixest <- partialling_out(model_fixest, data = penguins) tt(head(res_fixest)) |>   format_tt(digits = 2) |>   style_tt(align = "c") library(lfe)  model_lfe <- felm(bill_length_mm ~ bill_depth_mm | species, data = penguins)  res_lfe <- partialling_out(model_lfe, data = penguins)   tt(head(res_lfe)) |>   format_tt(digits = 2) |>   style_tt(align = "c")

title: partialling_out
text: far, interaction terms :, *, ^ (feols) well varying slopes feols [ [[ supported variables main explanatory variable, .e. supported, yield error. Therefore, main explanatory variable interaction, built outside model intend partial afterwards.
code: feols(bill_depth_mm ~ bill_length_mm | species^sex, data = penguins) |>   partialling_out(data = penguins) feols(bill_depth_mm ~ i(bill_length_mm, species) | sex, data = penguins) |>   partialling_out(data = penguins)

title: partialling_out
text: far, AsIs expressions, polynomial terms formula yet supported, two expressions yield error.
code: partialling_out(lm(bill_depth_mm ~ I(bill_length_mm^2) + species,                    data = penguins))  partialling_out(lm(bill_depth_mm ~  poly(bill_length_mm, 2) + species,                    data = penguins[!is.na(penguins$bill_length_mm), ]))

title: partialling_out
text: Results can displayed scatterplot either regular binned.  Plotting residuals equivalent following approach fwlplot
code: tinytheme("tufte") par(mfrow = c(2, 1))   tinyplot(res_fixest$res_bill_length_mm ~ res_fixest$res_bill_depth_mm) tinyplot_add(   res_fixest$res_bill_length_mm ~ res_fixest$res_bill_depth_mm,   type = "lm" )  res_fixest$qnt <- cut(   res_fixest$res_bill_depth_mm,   breaks = quantile(res_fixest$res_bill_depth_mm, probs = seq(0, 1, .02)),   include.lowest = TRUE )   res_qnt <- aggregate(   cbind(res_bill_depth_mm, res_bill_length_mm) ~ qnt,   data = res_fixest,   FUN = mean )  tinyplot(res_qnt$res_bill_length_mm ~ res_qnt$res_bill_depth_mm) tinyplot_add(   res_fixest$res_bill_length_mm ~ res_fixest$res_bill_depth_mm,   type = "lm" ) fwlplot(bill_length_mm ~ bill_depth_mm | species, data = penguins)

what: Adding other parameters to the model
title: partialling_out
text: parameters passed lm(), feols(), felm(), can passed partialling_out().
code: model_fixest <- feols(   bill_length_mm ~ bill_depth_mm | species + island,   data = penguins,   cluster = ~species )   tt(head(partialling_out(model_fixest, data = penguins, cluster = ~species))) |>   format_tt(digits = 2) |>   style_tt(align = "c")

title: partialling_out
text: authors fwlplot package, Kyle Butts Grant McDermott, provided inspiration ideas project. colleague Andreu Arenas-Jal insight guiding.

title: Contributing to partialling.out
text: outlines propose change partialling.. stable state development, active subsequent development primarily response user feedback. detailed discussion contributing tidyverse packages, please see development contributing guide code review principles.

title: Contributing to partialling.out
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to partialling.out
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See guide create great issue advice.

title: Contributing to partialling.out
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("ropensci/partialling.", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to partialling.out
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use tinytest unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to partialling.out
text: Please note partialling.project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Residuals from partial regressions
text: Partialling package allows generate residualised variables already existing linear fixed effects models. far works lm, felm (lfepackage) feols (fixest package) applications Frisch-Waugh-Lovell theorem, explained Lovell (2008). Whereas algorithm already implemented fwlplot, package offers three new characteristics. uses already existing model instead formula. Works lm felm objects alongside feols. Returns data.frame residualised variables instead plot, thus offering freedom results.

title: Residuals from partial regressions
text: Frisch-Waugh-Lovell theorem states linear model coefficient  equivalent coefficient, , regression  residuals regression    residuals regression  .  theorem designed help simplifying linear , particularly, fixed effects models easier visualisation interpretation, transforming multiple regression simple one can easily visualised via scatterplot used models.
code: Y = X_1 \beta_1 + X_2 \beta_2 + u M_{X_2} Y = M_{X_2} X_1 \beta_1 + M_{X_1} u

title: Residuals from partial regressions
text: can install development version partialling.GitHub :

title: Residuals from partial regressions
text: workflow partialling.rather simple: first, create linear fixed effects model. Using partialling_out function, can get residualised variable interest (bill length) first explanatory variable (bill_length), .e. return residuals following two regressions.
code: library(partialling.out) library(tinytable) library(tinyplot) library(palmerpenguins)  model <- lm(bill_length_mm ~ bill_depth_mm + species, data = penguins) summary(model) #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = bill_length_mm ~ bill_depth_mm + species, data = penguins) #>  #> Residuals: #>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max  #> -8.0300 -1.5828  0.0733  1.6925 10.0313  #>  #> Coefficients: #>                  Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)     #> (Intercept)       13.2164     2.2475    5.88 9.83e-09 *** #> bill_depth_mm      1.3940     0.1220   11.43  < 2e-16 *** #> speciesChinstrap   9.9390     0.3678   27.02  < 2e-16 *** #> speciesGentoo     13.4033     0.5118   26.19  < 2e-16 *** #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #> Residual standard error: 2.518 on 338 degrees of freedom #>   (2 observations deleted due to missingness) #> Multiple R-squared:  0.7892, Adjusted R-squared:  0.7874  #> F-statistic: 421.9 on 3 and 338 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16 modely <- lm(bill_length_mm ~ species, data = penguins) modelx <- lm(bill_depth_mm ~ species, data = penguins) res <- partialling_out(model, data = penguins)  tt(head(res)) |>   format_tt(digits = 2) |>   style_tt(align = "c")

title: Residuals from partial regressions
text: stated , follow following Frisch-Waugh-Lovell theorem coefficient res_bill_depth_mm model lm(res_bill_length_mm ~ res_bill_depth_mm) coefficient bill_depth_mm original model.
code: resmodel <- lm(res_bill_length_mm ~ res_bill_depth_mm, data = res)  print(c(model$coefficients[2], resmodel$coefficients[2])) #>     bill_depth_mm res_bill_depth_mm  #>          1.394011          1.394011

what: partialling.out: Residuals from partial regressions — partialling.out-package
title: partialling.out: Residuals from partial regressions — partialling.out-package
text: Creates data frame residuals partial regressions main explanatory variable variable interest. method follows Frisch-Waugh-Lovell theorem, explained Lovell (2008) doi:10.3200/JECE.39.1.88-91 .

title: partialling.out: Residuals from partial regressions — partialling.out-package
text: Maintainer: Marc Bosch-Matas mboschmatas@gmail.com (ORCID)

what: partialling_out: partialling out variable of interest and main — partialling_out
title: partialling_out: partialling out variable of interest and main — partialling_out
text: Creates data.frame residualised main explanatory variable , wanted, variable interest linear fixed effects model

title: partialling_out: partialling out variable of interest and main — partialling_out
partialling_out: partialling out variable of interest and main — partialling_out
text: model object want residualise variables data data.frame used original model. Using different data return unexpected results error. weights numeric vector weighting partial models. Length must equal number rows data TRUE residualise variable interest first explanatory variable model. FALSE, latter. Set TRUE default na.rm TRUE remove observations NA models run. FALSE, underlying lm, feols, felm remove NA values errors may arise weights used. ... lm, feols, felm parameters passed partial regressions

title: partialling_out: partialling out variable of interest and main — partialling_out
text: data.frame (residualised) variable interest residualised main explanatory variable

title: partialling_out: partialling out variable of interest and main — partialling_out
text: function regresses main (.e. first model) explanatory variable variable interest (parameter set TRUE) control variables fixed effects returns residuals data.frame accept lm, felm (lfe package), feols (fixest package) objects

title: partialling_out: partialling out variable of interest and main — partialling_out
code: library(palmerpenguins) #>  #> Attaching package: ‘palmerpenguins’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:datasets’: #>  #>     penguins, penguins_raw library(fixest) model <- feols(bill_length_mm ~ bill_depth_mm | species + island,                data = penguins) #> NOTE: 2 observations removed because of NA values (LHS: 2, RHS: 2). partial_df <- partialling_out(model, penguins, both = TRUE)
